home.title: Equreka
home.lead: Your free and open-source app for equations, formulas, variables, constants and units.

settings.title: Settings
settings.lead: This settings are stored in your device, we do not have any information of you in our servers

about.title: About us
about.lead: Equreka is a 100% free and ad-free, open-source platform for everyone. Hopefully you will find this usefull and will inspire to learn more, create and contribute to human-kind.
about.paragraph: You can contribute in many ways, from sharing to contributing directly to the project in our Github.

free-and-open-source.title: Free and Open-source? <small class="text-muted">where is the catch?</small>
free-and-open-source.lead: There is NO catch, it's as simple as that. By being open-source, the project obtains reliability, transparency and gives the opportunity for anyone (who wants to) to contribute and do their bit.

quote.paragraph: I firmly believe that knowledge should be free, open, easily accessible and if can be, as easy to understand as possible.
quote.author: Derian, Creator of Equreka

thanks.title: Special thanks to
thanks.lead: Science and all the people that creates awesome stuff, all philosophers, all alchemists, all scientists, to all those people who contributed to science, to civilization, to humanity. All open source projects and specially the ones that made possible this project
thanks.paragraph: Here are some projects (in alphabetical order) that made this project possible:
thanks.check-github: You can check our Github for a more complete list in our source-code.

contact.lead: Feel free to send a message if you want to say something to us!
contact.placeholder-message: What do you want to share to us?
contact.title: Contact us

donate.lead: Donations will help us to improve, add new features, organize and pay for all the infrastructure needed.
donate.title: Donate
donate.paragraph: If you like what we do and the platform you can help us by sharing and if you want you can donate.

faq.lead: In this page you can find some of the *possible* questions you can have about Equreka
faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions

why-is-free.anwser: As we stated in the page about: knowledge should be free, open, easily accessible and if can be, as easy to understand as possible.
why-is-free.question: Why is it free?

why-no-signup.anwser: We live in a world where most platforms, sites or apps require a form of authentication, whether by creating an account or registration through a social network, where there is no transparency, there is no clarity or there are always small letters difficult to see, to know how they will handle our data that is collected. There have been many leaks from large companies and guaranteeing said security is a very difficult task. Equreka does not need any type of information from you, we will not collect data on our servers, we handle APIs directly in the browser that are stored on your computer and that you can see what information is being stored on YOUR computer.
why-no-signup.question: Why don't there is no user signup?

report.input-placeholder-reason: Tell us what did you find... üòß
report.lead: Reporting errors are very important for us, thank you for taking your time to do it!
report.title: Report this page

chemistry.lead: Chemistry is the scientific discipline involved with elements and compounds made up of atoms, molecules and ions: their composition, structure, properties, behavior and the changes they undergo during a reaction with other substances.
chemistry.title: Chemistry

mathematics.lead: Mathematics (from Greek: ŒºŒ¨Œ∏Œ∑ŒºŒ±, m√°thƒìma, 'knowledge, study, learning') includes the study of such topics as quantity (number theory), structure (algebra), space (geometry) and change (analysis) . It does not have a generally accepted definition.
mathematics.title: Mathematics

physics.lead: Physics (from ancient Greek: œÜœÖœÉŒπŒ∫ŒÆ (·ºêœÄŒπœÉœÑŒÆŒºŒ∑), romanized: physik·∏ó (epist·∏ómƒì), literally 'knowledge of nature', from œÜœçœÉŒπœÇ ph√Ωsis 'nature') is the natural science that studies matter, its movement and behavior across space and time, and the related entities of energy and force. Physics is one of the most fundamental scientific disciplines and its main objective is to understand how the universe behaves.
physics.title: Physics

universal.lead: Within science there are properties that can be applied to different branches, this is known as a universal property, for example constants and units. In this category you can find them all.
universal.title: Universal

equations.title: Equations
equations.description: In mathematics, an equation is a statement that asserts the equality of two expressions, which are connected by the equal sign.

formulas.title: Formulas
formulas.description: In science, a formula is a concise way of expressing information symbolically, as in a mathematical formula or a chemical formula. The informal use of the term formula in science refers to the general construct of a relationship between given quantities.

constants.title: Constants
constants.description: A well-defined, fixed number or other mathematical object that does not vary. The terms mathematical constant or physical constant are sometimes used to distinguish this meaning.

magnitudes.title: Magnitudes
magnitudes.description: A physical quantity is a measurable quantity of a physical system to which different values ‚Äã‚Äãcan be assigned as a result of a measurement or a relation of measurements. Physical quantities are measured using a standard that has that quantity well defined. , and taking as a unit the amount of that property that the master object possesses.

units.title: Units
units.description: A unit of measure is a standardized quantity of a certain physical quantity, defined and adopted by convention or by law. Any value of a physical quantity can be expressed as a multiple of the unit of measure.

variables.title: Variables
variables.description: A variable is a symbol that functions as a placeholder for expressions or quantities that can vary or change; it is often used to represent the argument of a function or an arbitrary element of a set. In addition to numbers, variables are commonly used to represent vectors, matrices, and functions.
